intro: Comocladia mayana, commonly known as the mayana sea grapes, is a tropical plant native to the Caribbean and parts of Central America. It is a member of the Guttiferae family and is characterized by its small, fleshy, red berries that resemble grapes. The plant typically grows in coastal areas and is often found in mangrove swamps or saltwater environments. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and have a smooth texture, while its stems are woody and can become quite sprawling. The fruit is edible and has a sweet, tangy flavor, making it a popular ingredient in local cuisines.
